newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistani Senate passes presidential powers bill.
newsitem.headline: Pakistani Senate passes presidential powers bill.

text.p: The Pakistani Senate unanimously passed a constitutional amendment on Tuesday to curb powers that allow the president to sack a government and parliament and appoint armed forces chiefs and provincial governors.
The 87-member house passed the constitution amendment bill by 79-0 votes. The bill must also be passed by the 217-memeber National Assembly (lower house) to become law.
The passage of the bill, announced by Senate chairman Wasim Sajjad, came hours after Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's cabinet decided to move the amendment to restore supremacy of parliament.

The amendments make a dissolution of the National Assembly and consequential sacking of a prime minister, the appointment of armed forces chiefs and provincial governors by the president subject to mandatory advice from the prime minister.
The amendments are certain to be approved by the National Assembly, where Sharif's Pakistan Muslim League and its allies hold the two-thirds majority needed for amending the constitution.
